# Voice Profile for Cody1

## Core Tone & Persona
Cody1's writing exudes a passionate, hopeful, and authoritative tone. The persona is that of a spiritual guide, deeply rooted in biblical scripture, aiming to inspire and uplift through vivid imagery and historical context. The writing is imbued with a sense of urgency and conviction, encouraging perseverance and faithfulness in the face of adversity.

## Audience Lens
Cody1 envisions an audience of believers seeking encouragement and strength in their faith. The writing addresses those familiar with biblical narratives and historical Christian persecution, aiming to provide them with hope and a sense of divine justice. The audience is encouraged to see themselves as part of a larger, victorious narrative.

## Structural Preferences
- **Length & Layout**: Long-form, sermon-like structure with multiple sections.
- **Pacing**: Alternates between detailed exposition and calls to action.
- **Narrative Style**: Uses historical and biblical narratives to frame contemporary issues.

## Lexical & Rhetorical Signatures
- **Repetition**: "God’s victory is declared in our Worship," "Our God wins, so now we sing."
- **Metaphors**: "Sea of glass mingled with fire," "Worship is our weapon."
- **Questions**: "Do you sense the hope there?" "What beast is roaring at you?"
- **Biblical References**: Frequent citations from Revelation, Deuteronomy, and other scriptures.

## Do/Don’t Guardrails
- **Do**:
  - Use vivid biblical imagery.
  - Encourage perseverance and worship.
  - Cite scripture to support arguments.
- **Don’t**:
  - Avoid secular language or non-biblical references.
  - Do not downplay the seriousness of judgment.
  - Avoid overly simplistic solutions to complex issues.

## Sample Snippet
Imagine standing on the edge of a vast, fiery sea, the air thick with the echoes of triumphant songs. This is not just a vision of the end; it's a call to live boldly now. As believers, we are not mere spectators but active participants in God's unfolding story. Our worship today is a declaration of faith, a testament to the victory already won. So, when trials come, remember: our God reigns, and His justice will prevail. Stand firm, sing loud, and let your life be a beacon of hope.

---

**Methodology Note**: This profile was developed using a combination of quantitative analysis of sentence structure and lexical patterns, alongside qualitative insights into thematic and rhetorical elements.

From Judgment to Joy: Singing the Victors’ Song at the Sea of Glass

Please open to Revelation 15

Revelation 15:1-4 NKJV
Then I saw another sign in heaven, great and marvelous: seven angels having the seven last plagues, for in them the wrath of God is complete. [2] And I saw something like a sea of glass mingled with fire, and those who have the victory over the beast, over his image and over his mark and over the number of his name, standing on the sea of glass, having harps of God. [3] They sing the song of Moses, the servant of God, and the song of the Lamb, saying: "Great and marvelous are Your works, Lord God Almighty! Just and true are Your ways, O King of the saints! [4] Who shall not fear You, O Lord, and glorify Your name? For You alone are holy. For all nations shall come and worship before You, For Your judgments have been manifested."

In these verses, John describes a powerful image: 
"a sea of glass mingled with fire," and God’s people standing by that fiery sea, singing triumphantly. 
It’s a vision of judgment and peace, fire and calm, beautifully intertwined. 
Those standing there aren't just spectators; they’re survivors who overcame evil. 
Their song—the Song of Moses and the Song of the Lamb—is a chorus celebrating victory and redemption.

Deuteronomy 32 records the song of moses:

Deuteronomy 32:3-4 NKJV
For I proclaim the name of the LORD: Ascribe greatness to our God. [4] He is the Rock, His work is perfect; For all His ways are justice, A God of truth and without injustice; Righteous and upright is He.

Deuteronomy 32:39 NKJV
'Now see that I, even I, am He, And there is no God besides Me; I kill and I make alive; I wound and I heal; Nor is there any who can deliver from My hand.

Deuteronomy 32:43 NKJV
"Rejoice, O Gentiles, with His people; For He will avenge the blood of His servants, And render vengeance to His adversaries; He will provide atonement for His land and His people."


Let me share why this matters to us. 
When John penned Revelation, Christians were under intense persecution from Rome. 
Their world was literally burning.
 Jerusalem had fallen catastrophically, the Temple destroyed. 
The historian Josephus tells chilling stories of desperation: 
famine so severe people ate leather to survive. 
Even darker, a mother driven by hunger cooking her child. 
It’s almost too much to comprehend.

The early church historian Eusebius later saw Jerusalem's destruction clearly as divine judgment for rejecting Jesus. 
Yet, even amidst that terror, God protected His own. 
Before Jerusalem fell, Christians were warned to flee to safety in a town called Pella. 
Judgment fell, but God’s faithful were saved. 
Can you feel the weight of that? 
Judgment may come, but grace is waiting for those who listen.

This is the reality John’s audience knew firsthand—brutal judgment, but also miraculous deliverance. 
Many asked, 
"Lord, where is justice? 
Are we really on the winning side?" 
Revelation 15 provides the clear, confident answer: 
God’s judgment might be delayed, but it will never be denied.
 Evil will fall. 
Faithfulness will stand.

Picture again John’s vision: 
Seven angels holding the last plagues of God’s wrath. It reminds us of Moses and Pharaoh.
Just as Egypt faced ten plagues to free God's people, now seven final plagues are coming to fully and finally defeat evil. 
Scripture calls it “great and marvelous”—a decisive moment when divine patience runs out. 
Justice will be served, completely.

Then the vision shifts to that sea of glass, now mingled with fire—heaven’s purity touched by the flames of judgment. 
It’s an impossible blend, yet in God’s realm, judgment and mercy perfectly coexist. 
And standing safely on this fiery sea are those who faced the world’s worst evils—the beast, its image, its oppressive power—and didn’t bow. 
These victors were everyday heroes, believers who refused to declare "Caesar is Lord," even under threat of death. 
John sees them alive and triumphant, safe on God’s shore, looking back at defeated evil.

Do you sense the hope there? 
The most frightening forces—the Roman Empire, oppressive rulers, death itself—will be utterly defeated, and God's people will stand fearlessly, with hearts full of song.

Notice carefully what they’re doing. 
They aren’t celebrating themselves. 
No victory laps here. 
They are singing. 
Singing the song of Moses and the Lamb. 
Moses’ song celebrated liberation from Egypt; 
now it blends seamlessly with the Lamb’s song celebrating our greater deliverance from sin through the cross and resurrection. 
The Exodus foreshadowed a greater rescue—the Passover pointed toward Christ’s sacrifice.

Listen to their song’s powerful words:
"Great and marvelous are Your works, Lord God Almighty! Just and true are Your ways, O King of the saints! Who shall not fear You, O Lord, and glorify Your name? For You alone are holy. All nations shall come and worship before You, for Your judgments have been manifested."

It’s not a sad song; it’s triumphant. 
They're declaring, “Lord, You proved Yourself faithful. Every nation will see Your justice.” 
This song vindicates God's character. 
Maybe today, you’ve wondered why injustice seems unchecked, why good people suffer. 
This song promises that a day is coming when the truth about God’s fairness will be undeniable. 
All nations—even former skeptics—will bow in worship.

This victory song is our song. 
The core truth of this vision is simple: "God’s victory is declared in our Worship." 
We don't sing because life is easy; 
We sing because we trust His victory, even when life is hard.
Let this sink in. 
Picture that fiery sea, the victorious crowd, our holy God receiving His due worship. 
Imagine yourself there—because if you belong to Jesus, that is indeed your destination.

This vision calls us to persevere and worship boldly. 
Let it strengthen your heart and lift your voice today. 
Because one day soon, we’ll all join in heaven’s anthem.
"God’s victory is declared in our Worship."


God’s Purpose in Judgement

Revelation 15 makes something clear: 
God’s judgment is real, and it's good. 
John saw "seven angels having the seven last plagues, for in them the wrath of God is complete" (Rev 15:1). 
That phrase stops us cold—the wrath of God is complete. 
Finished. 
Filled up. 
It reminds us that evil and injustice won’t last forever. 
I know judgment isn’t a comfortable topic; 
it’s tough to hear. 
But think about this: 
would we truly love a God who stayed indifferent toward cruelty? 
Could we worship a God who shrugs at Auschwitz, who turns away from child abuse or human trafficking?
No, we couldn’t. 

God's justice means evil has an expiration date. 
Revelation 15 shows a moment when God finally says, "Enough. No more." 
Those bowls of wrath in the next chapter aren't random punishment—they’re purposeful cleansing, setting things right once and for all.

What does this mean practically? 

It means we can trust God’s justice instead of losing hope or taking revenge ourselves. 

Romans 12:19 NKJV
Beloved, do not avenge yourselves, but rather give place to wrath; for it is written, "Vengeance is Mine, I will repay," says the Lord.

We can overcome evil with good because we trust God will ultimately overcome evil Himself.

The early church needed this reminder. 
They saw Rome’s brutality firsthand. 
They watched Israel compromise themselves and partner with Rome in the persecution of the Church.
To the human eye, it seemed meaningless, but Jesus predicted that tragedy decades earlier:

Luke 19:41-44 NKJV
Now as He drew near, He saw the city and wept over it, [42] saying, "If you had known, even you, especially in this your day, the things that make for your peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes. [43] For days will come upon you when your enemies will build an embankment around you, surround you and close you in on every side, [44] and level you, and your children within you, to the ground; and they will not leave in you one stone upon another, because you did not know the time of your visitation."

God patiently delayed judgment, calling His people to repentance. 
Josephus, the historian, recorded unusual signs—a sword-shaped star over Jerusalem, voices in the temple crying out warnings. 
Yet they ignored these signs, and judgment came.


But notice this: 
When judgment fell, the faithful had already been safely led out.

We see this pattern again and again. 
Judgment for one group brings redemption for another. 
Think of Pharaoh at the Red Sea: 
The waters that crushed Pharaoh’s army were the very same waters that stood aside so God’s people could walk free. 
Judgment and redemption go hand in hand, two sides of God’s perfect action in the world.

Here’s our invitation today, and it comes in two parts: 

A warning and a comfort.

First, the warning:

 Let’s not align ourselves with anything God must judge. 
Pride, bitterness, dishonesty—whatever Pharaoh-like spirit might linger in our hearts, let's deal with it now. 
God’s mercy holds back destruction, but only for so long. 
One Puritan writer put it vividly: “The sword of God’s justice may sleep, but it never rusts.” 
Eventually, unrepentant evil must face the music.

But second, here’s the comfort: 

If you belong to the Lamb, you live under mercy, not wrath. 
God’s judgment isn’t something to fear; it’s something to respect, yes—but also to praise Him for. 
Because judgment means your suffering will be vindicated and every enemy—sin, Satan, even death itself—will be overcome. 
How many times have we cried tears over injustice—a loved one lost to reckless tragedy, a faithful person mistreated? 
We might not see justice fully on this side of eternity, but Revelation 15 promises no one ultimately escapes accountability. 
Every Hitler, every oppressor, every unrepentant rebel faces true justice. 
And we will say “Hallelujah!” when God’s righteousness is fully revealed.

We can see this on display in the world right now.

Yesterday, new broke on about the US carrrying out an attack on Iran’s Nuclear facility. There was fire.

Some could view this as Judgement. 
Is that to say that those executing the attack are righteous.
No, not necessarily. The natural forces executing judgment are not indicators of alignment with Christ. 
Many times, God used secular nations to carry out his judgement against evil nations.

Here’s the reality, Iran is one of the leading nations that persecute Christians. 

In 2024, there was a sixfold increase of Christians imprisoned and sentenced in Iran.
Iran accounts for 15% of all religious freedom prisoner worldwide.
Iran executed over 900 civilians in 2024 alone, many on charges directly related to religious beliefs or practices.
Iran scored a 0 on a scale of 0-4 for religious freedom.
Christinas must worship in secrecy in Iran.
90% of the documented cases of persecution involved converts from Islam
Conversion from Islam and evangelism are punishable by imprisonment or even death under Iran’s penal code.

Though the attack doesn’t speak to either US or Israel always being righteous, it does show us:

God will not allow his church to suffer forever. He will bring judgment against her oppressors and justice for the oppressed.


Dictators fall, captives are freed, reminding us that evil won’t have the last word. God will.

Rather than fear, this truth leads us to worship. 
Revelation’s victors sing: “Just and true are Your ways… Your judgments have been manifested” (Rev 15:3-4). 
They rejoice because God refuses to forever tolerate cruelty or unbelief.

Are we living in light of this promise? 

It should make us humble, knowing without Christ, we'd face judgment too. 
It should make us hopeful, trusting every sacrifice, every moment of integrity, will be worth it when God balances the scales. 
Instead of vengeance, we can forgive. 
Instead of despair over daily news, we can quietly pray, “Lord, I trust You’ll sort this out. Maranatha—come, Lord, and do justice.”

Early Christians faced persecution without bitterness, praying even for their persecutors, trusting fully in God's justice. 
Tradition tells us Polycarp worshipped even as flames took his life. 
That’s what happens when we trust God’s ultimate control: 
judgment and salvation intertwined. 
We can sing through the fire because we know the fire won’t have the final say.

God's judgment clears the way for His new creation.

Take heart: evil doesn’t win—God will, God will.

Victory Through the Lamb 

This passage speaks to how we win—not by force, not by compromise, but by holding fast to the Lamb of God.

John describes a crowd in Revelation who “have the victory over the beast” (Rev. 15:2). 
These weren’t warriors with swords or politicians with power. 
They were ordinary believers—some who paid with their lives. 

How did they conquer? 

Revelation 12:11 NKJV
And they overcame him by the blood of the Lamb and by the word of their testimony, and they did not love their lives to the death.

Their weapon wasn’t strength; it was faithfulness.

Here’s the challenge: 

When we hear “victory,” we picture winning a fight, coming out on top. 
But in God’s kingdom, victory often looks like surrender. 
Jesus conquered sin by dying on the cross. 
Friday seemed like defeat—Sunday proved it was triumph. 
The world may call us weak when we refuse to cut corners, when we choose integrity over influence, when we love instead of lash out. 
But God sees an overcomer. 
Every time you say, “No, I won’t bend on what Jesus says is right,” you’re defeating the beast.

John’s vision shows the saints standing on a sea of glass, holding harps (Rev. 15:2). 
Harps, not swords. 
Their battle was fought with worship, their victory won through patient faith. 
One day, the contrast will be undeniable. 
The beast’s followers may laugh now, but when the dust settles, only the faithful remain, singing. 

Psalm 30:5 NKJV
For His anger is but for a moment, His favor is for life; Weeping may endure for a night, But joy comes in the morning.

The morning after the long night belongs to God’s people.

So what does victory look like for us? 

It looks like perseverance. 
Like holding onto Jesus tighter than we cling to comfort, reputation, or even safety. 
That’s not easy—but grace meets us there. 
Revelation’s letters to the churches repeat this promise: “To him who overcomes…” (Rev. 2-3). 
The reward isn’t for the strong-armed, but for the steadfast.

Let’s get practical. 

You may not face lions, but maybe a workplace where honesty costs you a promotion. 
Maybe our kids face a social beast—pressure to trade their faith for acceptance. 
Maybe you’ve been called “too religious” for doing the right thing. 
These are today’s battlefields. 

How do we overcome? 

By refusing to let the world mold us.
By loving when hate is loud. 
By singing before the breakthrough comes.

Paul and Silas sang in prison at midnight.

Acts 16:25 NKJV
But at midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them.

Their praise shook the walls. Sometimes your song in the dark is what breaks chains—if not around you, within you. 

And history shows us: 

Early Christians didn’t overthrow Rome with revolt; 
they outlasted it with relentless love. 
The same Lamb who conquered death is still conquering—through ordinary people like us.

So here’s my question: 

What beast is roaring at you? 

Fear? 
Temptation? 
Pressure to stay silent? 

Remember, the mark of the beast was about allegiance—whose way will you follow? 

Every “no” to compromise is a “yes” to Christ. Every act of integrity, every stand taken in love, echoes in eternity.

You might feel weary, outnumbered.

 But listen: 

God calls you overcomer now, not just later. 

“This is the victory that has overcome the world—our faith” 

1 John 5:4 NKJV
For whatever is born of God overcomes the world. And this is the victory that has overcome the world-our faith.

 Not our strength—our trust in Jesus. So keep the faith. Keep the song. Fight with worship, with kindness, with quiet obedience. 

One day, Jesus will point to moments you thought were small and say, “Look how they overcame.”

Here’s the call: 

Persevere and praise. 
Live differently. 
Sing anyway. 

The sea of glass is before God’s throne—meaning He’s with you in the battle. You fight armored in His strength, covered by the Lamb’s blood. So you can’t lose in the long run.


Keep the faith. The victory’s already won.

Worship is Our Weapon and Our Destiny

This passage shows that worship is both our weapon and our destiny.

Sometimes, we think worship is something that comes after God does something great—like a victory celebration. 

But Revelation 15 paints a different picture. The heart of the vision isn’t plagues or even parted seas—it’s the song itself. 

 Revelation 15:3 NKJV
They sing the song of Moses, the servant of God, and the song of the Lamb, saying: "Great and marvelous are Your works, Lord God Almighty! Just and true are Your ways, O King of the saints!

Worship isn't just gratitude after victory—it's a powerful act that proclaims who God is even before the battle ends.

Think about the Israelites by the Red Sea. 

Their song wasn’t just a thank-you note
It was a bold announcement: Yahweh alone is mighty. 

Exodus 15 tells us clearly—when they sang, their enemies trembled and their own hearts filled with courage.
 Worship sends a message to everyone around us, even to spiritual darkness, declaring clearly who we trust. 
History tells us the early church sang hymns boldly, even under threat. It baffled outsiders—how could these people sing so joyfully amid persecution?

I know this to be true. 

I’ve got a lot going on recently with my new position. 
Trying to manage not only the Church, but family and work with high demands.
Everything is important, everything demands attention.
I let someone down everyday. 
There’s things that needed to be done each day that don’t get done, even after I spend 12 hours every day skipping lunch and working every second of that day. 
I have big shoulders and I can carry that, most days.
But there are days it’s too much.
I’ve had those more frequently in this season.

But, it’s nothing that worship cannot over come.

Stopping to worship before picking up Stan… A day that began in chaos ended with awe.

Isaiah 61 calls it trading our heaviness for a garment of praise. 

Isaiah 61:10-11 NKJV
I will greatly rejoice in the LORD, My soul shall be joyful in my God; For He has clothed me with the garments of salvation, He has covered me with the robe of righteousness, As a bridegroom decks himself with ornaments, And as a bride adorns herself with her jewels. [11] For as the earth brings forth its bud, As the garden causes the things that are sown in it to spring forth, So the Lord GOD will cause righteousness and praise to spring forth before all the nations.

Many of you know exactly what I mean:
you've sung through sorrow, 
at hospitals or gravesides, 
discovering comfort in God's presence. 
That’s victory. 
That’s our weapon.

So what's next? 

Make worship part of daily life. Not necessarily singing everywhere, though a hymn during a tough day never hurts. 
But intentionally keeping God's goodness and greatness in your heart. 

Revelation’s song gives us a model:

Praise His works (what He’s done), 
Praise His ways (always right, even when mysterious), 
Praise His holiness (pure, unmatched), 
and Praise His righteous action (justice revealed clearly to the world). 

Remember the exodus moments in your life—times God led you safely through. Praise Him for those moments.
But there's another side to worship:

our witness

Revelation 15 says, “All nations shall come and worship before You” 

Isaiah 61:10-11 NKJV
I will greatly rejoice in the LORD, My soul shall be joyful in my God; For He has clothed me with the garments of salvation, He has covered me with the robe of righteousness, As a bridegroom decks himself with ornaments, And as a bride adorns herself with her jewels. [11] For as the earth brings forth its bud, As the garden causes the things that are sown in it to spring forth, So the Lord GOD will cause righteousness and praise to spring forth before all the nations.

That's not just future prophecy; it's our call now. Every time we share Christ’s love, speak truth with kindness, or show compassion, we invite people to join heaven’s choir. 

There's always room for another voice.


Here in America, we can sing freely. 
Let's never take that for granted or sing half-heartedly. 
Let's sing like Moses' people by the sea, like believers who've known cost and persecution. 
Let's fill our homes with songs that anchor our families' faith.


Imagine someday your child facing trials, 
suddenly recalling how you quietly sang “It is Well with My Soul” in the kitchen. 
That memory becomes courage for their battles. 
That's the legacy worth leaving.


Worship draws a line: 

Who will we serve? 

Revelation asks, "Who shall not fear You and glorify Your name?" Ultimately, every knee bows 

Philippians 2:10-11 NKJV
that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those in heaven, and of those on earth, and of those under the earth, [11] and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

We choose now to sing joyfully, willingly, rather than later by compulsion.
The drama of redemption is a musical, and God has given each of us a part. 
So here's our action step: 

Worship daily, in word, song, and deed. 
Turn worries into praise, teach our families faith-songs, and let daily life echo with worship. 

Romans 12:1 NKJV
I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that you present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God, which is your reasonable service.

offer your life as worship—treating others well, stewarding money, speaking kindly at home.


Let’s be that "odd" community joyfully praising God amidst a cynical world—not blind optimism, but deep biblical hope. We know how the story ends. Our God wins, so we sing.
Let’s start now. Our song today prepares us for eternity, declaring God’s glory and spreading hope.
Let your life sing loud and clear: Our God wins and so we sing!

Summary and Conclusion 

We’ve walked through Revelation 15:1–4 together—standing with John in the throne room, watching the angels prepare for judgment, hearing the song of the victors rise over the fire and glass. 

It’s a vision of two things at once:

God’s justice will come
His people will rejoice

So what do we do with that? How does this change the way we face Monday morning?  

Let me put it simply: **Our God wins, so now we sing.** 
That’s the heartbeat of this passage.  

Right now, evil often looks strong, and faithfulness can feel small. But Revelation shouts the truth—God’s justice *will* roll down, and His people *will* stand victorious.  

So we live today with endurance, worship, and invitation.

3 Takeaways: 

Stay faithful

When the weight of the world makes you want to quit, remember the sea of glass and fire. 
Every trial faced with Christ is temporary. 
Every sacrifice for Him is seen. 
The early Christians outlasted Rome’s persecution. 
The Reformers outlived the darkness. 
And if you’re in the thick of it now, hold fast. 
Your faithfulness matters.
 As Paul said, *"Be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord"* 

1 Corinthians 15:58 NKJV
Therefore, my beloved brethren, be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labor is not in vain in the Lord.

Live worshipfully.

Don’t wait for the battle to end to sing—sing *now*. 
Worship is your birthright and your battery. 
The song in Revelation 15 is stitched together from Psalms and Exodus, a reminder that God’s people have always praised Him in the fire.
So let’s align our lives with His holiness.
If there’s an area where you’re cutting corners, set it right. 
That’s worship too.  

Invite others. 

The song says *"all nations will come and worship"*—so let’s be part of that. 
Share your story this week. 
Serve your neighbor. 
Every act of love is a note in heaven’s chorus. 
And keep the hope alive: Judgment isn’t doom—it’s the road to redemption. 
The time is *now* to sing and serve.  

Here’s a picture for you: 

Imagine driving west at sunset, cresting a hill, and seeing the ocean stretched out, the sky on fire, the water dancing with light. Now imagine hearing a thousand voices singing, *"Great and marvelous are Your works, Lord God Almighty!"* That’s where we’re headed. 
The trials? Temporary. 
The song? Eternal.  

So this week, practice being a person of the victory song. 
When bad news comes, pause and say, *"Lord, You are good."*
When you meet someone despairing, point them to the God who rescues. 
We don’t live in fear—the future belongs to our Father.  

Church, the curtain *will* fall on this age. But until then, we’ve got a song to sing and a mission to fulfill. Stand firm. Lift your voice. Live like you believe it.  

Stand firm, sing loud—the battle is won, and our God reigns.

Amen.
